reviewText: This film has some of the worst, most stupid lines of dialog ever recorded on film.Being a product that comes out of a JERRY BRESLER and a PETER GILMAN, the predictable themes are (1) White people are racist and bad; (2) race-mixing of Whites is encouraged; (3) White men in general are bad; (4) a White man as a politician cannot represent non-Whites; and so forth along those entirely predictable lines that, in 1962, were obviously and glaringly designed to push the leftist/Hollywood agenda.  Instead, as a propaganda piece, it fails on all counts, even as the most marginal entertainment.The entire plot line is not credible in 1962, even as an artificial device, because, as a result of WWII, by 1950 there were over 50,000 interracial marriages of U.S. servicemen with Asians (in Japan, Korea, Philippines, and throughout Asia).The sequence of events and plot development are just incongruous and preposterous.  It goes from bad to worse to more worse still and "badder and badder."

reviewText: Wow ! It had been awhile since I had seen this movie, but found it as true now as it was originally. My only criticism would be that the parts of Hawaiians went to actors who were popular at the time and not to real or Hapa Hawaiians. Of course we have Charleton Heston chewing up the scenery as usual, but you expect that in a Heston movie and the role sort of fit in this case.  My other critic would be the way it ended, but it was the 50's and if you just sit back and enjoy it (and the scenery) it's still a pretty good movie.

reviewText: This story is set in 1959 Hawaii. Charlton Heston plays 'King' Howland, a plantation owner who is running for senate. Yvette Mimeux plays Sloane, his much younger sister, recently returned from San Francisco after finishing college. With her, she has childhood chum, Paul Kahanna, (Bobby Darren) whom she has decided she wants to marry. Paul is 100% pure Hawaiian! Paul's mother, who regrets the loss of her ethnic group through intermarriage with Caucasians, never-the-less offers an engagement party at her house. King objects to the idea of marriage, and so does Sloane's sister-in-law, Laura. Laura arrived on the island many years ago to help raise Sloane after King's wife and son died in a tidal wave. Laura wants to marry King, but King's heart is small - he only wants no-strings sex with his girlfried, Mai Chen. But Mai has other plans; she wants to trap King into marriage by getting pregnant. Also thrown into the mix is Dr. Kahanna, Paul's half-Hawaiian/half Caucasian brother who despises the wealthy Howlands, yet is undeniably attracted to the beautiful, headstrong Sloane. The Howlands have always been a close-knit, unlikeable clan despite their extensive philanthropy. Will Sloane follow through with her plan to break away from Howland family traditions? Will King grow a heart? Will Mai and her slimy brother ruin King's chances to be elected senator? Will any ethnic Hawaiians be seen in this movie? One of my favorite scenes is where Paul and Sloane do a Hawaiian dance at their engagement party. A fun, soapy movie.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am down to my last 70 or so vhs movies. The seeming zillions of others have either been converted to dvd, replaced on dvd or burned to dvd from a movie channel. But this last 70, well, they are the question marks: Do I really want to replace them with the dvd's? Will they ever be broadcast on any of the movie channels I get? Do I just need to let them go because I've seen them enough?In the grand tradition of Susan Slade, From the Terrace, A Summer Place and all those other great, shlocky late 50's/early 60's grand morality plays, in strides big Heston himself.  Against the gorgeous backdrop of a seemingly untouched Hawaii, Heston dispenses double-standarded philosophy, a "black and white" view of things, and he rules those around him with a moneyed, overbearing iron hand.Diamond Head has it all: out of wedlock sex and birth, death - accidental and otherwise, wealthy white men and considerably less well off indigenous people,  cross-ethnic "forbidden" love and ultimate marginal redemption.For movies of this ilk to be appreciated, one has to understand the times - and not take these films very seriously.  Diamond Head borders on the truly laughable, but still manages to be highly entertaining.If you are a fan of the 60's Big Star Melodramas, don't miss this one. It's got all the trappings AND Hawaii!
summary: Great 1960's melodrama fun! I mean it!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This 1962 film is set in Hawaii and, considering that it had just become a state a mere three years before, certainly captured the public's imagination and interest.  Charlton Heston is cast as a wealthy widower whose sister, Yvette Mimieux, is in love with a Polynesian, played by James Darren.  He vehemently objects to the marriage on racial grounds, but has no problem having his own little inter-racial affair with France Nuyen. Complications arise, especially when Nuyen becomes pregnant. There is a violent incident when the future bridegroom is murdered, and his doctor brother, George Chakiris, gets into a romance with Yvette Mimieux.  The whole film is about racial intolerance and it sends a strong message, which kept the story interesting.  The acting was good and Yvette Mimieux, then 20 years old, was a pleasure to look at.  The setting was beautiful too; I can never get tired of looking at films set in Hawaii.However, there was just a bit too much melodrama for my taste and although the story moved fast and was well plotted, I never felt any real emotion for the characters. And, as in the 60s, most of the people who were supposed to be Polynesian were really Caucasian actors with darkened skin, thereby losing authenticity. Usually, this kind of casting makes me angry, but this time I just relaxed and enjoyed the video, which was pleasant, dealt with a controversial theme, and was easy to follow.  But we can't expect all movies to be works of art.  Therefore, despite its faults, I give this film a lightweight recommendation.
summary: A bit too much melodrama , but I love films about Hawaii

reviewText: We love Hawaii and have been there several times, we also love Chuck Heston. This film covers the modern developing days of Hawaii 50-60's and gives a glimpse of how the rich and powerful influenced and help establish our 50th state and its development. It also deals with bigotry, old taboos, social injustice, the fruit of hatred and forbidden love.  Pineapples, sugar cane, farms, ranches and estates are the background to what many consider the most beautiful place on our planet. We are two of them that concur that Hawaii is the most beautiful place on the planet.

reviewText: Diamond Head is a movie I saw in 1963 and loved it then...and I still love it.  Charleston Heston is "Charleston Heston" (he always had a huge presence and it is evident in this movie). I have loved George Chakiris since West Side Story and I enjoyed him in this.  It is a B-movie but I love it.  France Nuyen, James Darren and Yvette Mimieux round out the main characters.  So if you just want to see a love story on two levels and like any of the above mention actors you should enjoy it as much as I did! Excellent rendition of double standards in society!

reviewText: I remember this movie when it came out, so that really "dates" me.  I was young when it was released, and I loved the stars of it (well most of them) and it was the beginning of a love affair with Hawaii.  The story line is old, it's that outdated stuff about prejudice over skin color, that is similar to the West Side Story theme and others of that time.  But I really enjoy the acting of everyone in this (although not a Charlton Heston fan) and although I am younger than Yvette Mimeux as a young girl I thought she was so beautiful and I was such a fan of hers.  Also back in those days I was a James Darren fan  (especially being a South Philly girl myself as a child) despite his small role in this and also a George Chakaris fan and I so enjoy the acting and the beautiful scenery.  If you are young and you don't care for old movies, this won't do it for you.  If you're older like me, it could bring back some memories.  If you just enjoy movies, you will like it.

reviewText: Diamond Head started life as a Clark Gable project and it probably should have died with him. At heart there's an interesting enough dilemma - what happens when Charlton Heston's outwardly liberal and benign business `King' of his part of Hawaii (quite what business he's King of is never made clear) is faced with the prospect of sister Yvette Mimieux marrying Hawaiian James Darren? - but quickly descends into TV movie soap opera bathos as scandal threatens to destroy his political ambitions and his family. By the time it's drawing to a close, a laughably Freudian dream scene makes it clear that his problem isn't so much that she wants to marry a native but that she isn't marrying him...There are surprisingly strong supporting performances from George Chakiris, Aline MacMahon and France Nuyen as Heston's lover (he'll happily sleep with her, but he'll be damned if he'll accept their illegitimate half-caste son as his heir) and in the early stages the film does at least acknowledge that racism exists on both sides, but in director Guy Green's hands it's dreary, passionless stuff. He can't even generate any excitement in a hypothetically inflammatory dance scene between Mimieux and Darren that's supposed to set Chucky thinking dark thoughts but actually looks like the kind of thing you might see in a badly choreographed elementary school play performed by two pupils who've only just met and were threatened with detention if they didn't do it. Definitely soft-soap all round.No extras on Sony's Region 1 NTSC DVD, which has an unexceptional 2.35:1 widescren transfer.
summary: "I've about had a gut full of you Kahannaas!"
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is one of the true classic movies that are made no more.  It is the story of inter-racial love and how its fallout can destroy the lives of families, friends and traditions.  The beautiful scenery of Hawaii and acting of stars like Charlton Heston and Yvette Mimieux make it all the better.  For those who truly love the films of yesterday, that relied on REAL acting to convey a story rather than graphic, shabby sex to convey a love story, this is a movie you will like!  .
summary: Beautiful setting in Hawaii, great love story!
